entry.title: Levels of analysis in agent based modeling
entry.content:
When talking about agent based modeling and refering to models as “Level 0” or “Level 1” I am often asked to explain these what these levels entail. When talking about levels in agent based modeling most modelers have this paper by Robert L. Axtell and Joshua L. Epstein in mind. They introduced four progressive levels in the sense that satisfactory performance of a model at level N implies that it is also satisfactory at level N-i:

Level 0: The model is a caricature of reality, as established through the use of simple graphical devices (e.g., allowing visualization of agent motion);

Level 1: The model is in qualitative agreement with empirical macro- structures, as established by plotting, say, distributional properties of the agent population;

Level 2: The model produces quantitative agreement with empirical macrostructures, as established through on-board statistical estimation routines; and finally,

Level 3: The model exhibits quantitative agreement with empirical microstructures, as determined from cross-sectional and longitudinal analysis of the agent population.

entry.title: Creating a Github Blog Using Octopress
entry.content:
With Octopress, I write my blog posts in Markdown. Octopress uses Jekyll that runs with Github pages.

Markdown offers a clean and simple syntax for text formating, translates fast and easily to HTML. It’s flexibility allows for outputing files into a wide array of formats, that are implicitly cross-platform.

Several third party Octopress themes are available here. There are several resources to help you get started with Octopress, such as the following:

  • Blog With Octopress and Github Pages)
  • Creating a Github Pages Blog With Octopress
  • Blogging With Octopress here and here

The documentation on the Octopress is pretty good too. Enjoy!
